column3:
ACK

The filename `developer-notes.md` could also be something like `guidelines-for-developers` (or similar). Because developer-notes could also imply that this are notes from the developers. But english is not my main-play.
Fixed a typo, and added @laanwj's explanation of ACK.\n
I typically use ACK these days to mean "Untested ACK, but I don't think this requires testing". Maybe I'm alone :)\n
@sipa That's the same place I use them, i.e. comments and documentation changes are prime examples.\n
Uh, check your file name... You seem to have a double extension.\n
Have fixed the double extension, thanks @Michagogo \n
Is a Tested ACK not just an ACK :)?\n
No, a loose ACK is ambigious. Avoid them unless it's a documentation/comment only change in which case there is nothing to test so the tested/untested distinction is not there.\n

I nit is simply a small comment. It comes from 'nitpicking' which is English, which means 'to be excessively concerned with or critical of inconsequential details'. It's a kind of self-criticizing at time same time. 'I like it slightly better like this but it isn't really important'...\nIt's a kind of silly colloquialism and doesn't belong in this 'formal' list.\n
